website_summaries.verdict: The Lytro lives up to its promise of capturing images that you can focus after they've been shot, but its image quality and ergonomics are poor, making the camera little more than an overpriced toy.

customer_reviews.title: Great experiment / toy. Not yet a camera.
customer_reviews.text: Love the new idea of light vectors being used. However, there are setbacks. Image quality is poor compared to what you expect from a digitial camera. The software is not that easy to use and it is quite hard to get a good picture to really be able to get the most out of the aperture/depth of field and focus settings on the software. Major adjustments and functions from the software are only available for the new mirrorless-style Lytro camera. Good for experimenting and trying something new. Not functional as an all around camera.
customer_reviews.author: Walter

customer_reviews.title: NO SUPPORT by LYTRO!
customer_reviews.text: At first, when these cameras came out, I thought it was a brilliant idea and it would be fun to have one for alternative shots. I bought the camera late in the game and just a couple of months after I purchased it, Lytro decided to get rid of their website (where you can download your photos) and now there is ZERO support for this product! What's the use of having this when I can't download the photos or use them? DO NOT BUY THIS ITEM. You will have no support.
customer_reviews.author: A. Hovanesian

customer_reviews.title: Magnetic cap is easily knocked off
customer_reviews.text: Paid 59 for the unit. Magnetic cap is easily knocked off. Rear screen isn't set back at all and could be easily scratched (though hasn't gotten scratched yet, but that's only with light useage). Screen difficult to see in bright light. Images are good. Easy to work with using their software, just point and shoot and you get the varying focus sort of photo that this is made to take. Photos are good quality on a computer screen/in a webpage, which is how the service seems to be intended to work. I don't think the 'limited' resolution is much of a big deal if you're not projecting onto a giant wall.
customer_reviews.author: R from N

customer_reviews.title: new learning curve
customer_reviews.text: I am still getting accustomed to this camera. It is quite different from most point and shoots and the software used for processing the pictures is also very different . It seems to be good at taking close ups at very close distances of flowers,bugs,etc. I will need to play with it a lot more to realize its full feature set.
customer_reviews.author: dimmer

customer_reviews.title: meh
customer_reviews.text: I got this on sale because I was incredibly curious about this device, but couldn't justify tinkering with a $300 toy. I am really glad I did get it on sale because otherwise I would be sorely disappointed. The concept behind being able to change the focus of the image is great. The actual execution and final product is disappointing. The quality of the images is poor at best, and really takes away from the experience. On the upside, it ended up being the cheapest digital camera I could give my (responsible) kid to play around with so I'll keep it, and hope the technology improves.
customer_reviews.author: Soleil

customer_reviews.title: Brilliant Camera with Fatal Flaws
customer_reviews.text: I love the function and results of this camera. Amazing photos. However, it has a fatal flaw. The camera is useless without the Lytro software and the Lytro software is useless without the camera. Highly proprietary with little support from the open source community or otherwise. It didn't take me long to have problems with firmware/software issues. Right now, I can't access any new photos on the camera because the software doesn't sense that it is connected to my computer. Also, the software will not install on 32 bit systems or iPad 2 or less. When it all works, it's brilliant.
customer_reviews.author: Kenneth Gillam

customer_reviews.title: A nice toy at best.
customer_reviews.text: I certainly don't think I would've been happy buying this camera at full price, but at $60 it's a nice toy. Taking light field photos is fun, but the first gen's small image size and image quality leave a but to be desired. Even in optimal conditions photos aren't as sharp as I'd like. As others have said, you definitely need to compose your photos and take foreground/background objects into consideration for the best results. The Lytro Illum, Lytro's second generation camera, takes MUCH better photos but comes and a premium price. Hopefully in a few years those will become more affordable as well, as light field photography really does feel like technology from the future.
customer_reviews.author: G. Valentine

customer_reviews.title: Limited Windows and No Chrome(Book/Box) support
customer_reviews.text: I received this on time, but I received a Graphite colored instead of the Moxie Pink, which was ordered. This is designed more towards the iPhone iOS than towards any other OS, although the Windows version of the software is ok. There are not versions that will run with Android or Chromebook/Chromebox systems. I do understand that Chrome has a small sector of the OS market, but it is growing, especially with companies deploying more weekly. Over all, I gave it 4 stars since it is limited in what it can do within the various OS's and Windows App.
customer_reviews.author: J Albert

customer_reviews.title: Not ready for consumer market
customer_reviews.text: I had trouble charging the batteries. Figured that out by experimenting with various charging devices--my computer doesn't seem to work. Took a few photos with a subject up close and far away per their instructions. Uploaded photo to proprietary image software to make the photos like the ads/website. That's pretty much where any progress stops. I go to website to view instructional videos and there are a lot more about their $1300 camera. Not ready for mass consumer market.
customer_reviews.author: J. T. Webb

customer_reviews.title: You may want to wait a while...
customer_reviews.text: The Lytro is a novel idea with great potential but isn't quite ready for prime time. If you are looking for quick low quality pics to post on a blog or facebook you may be satisfied with the results. If you are serious about photography however, you will be very disappointed with the image quality of the photos. The camera itself is built very well and is easy to use. After shooting a few hundred pictures with it, I consider it more of a toy than a camera. It should probably be priced more in the $125 range than $499. Hopefully the image quality will improve through software upgrades and someday it may be a great product.
customer_reviews.author: Gadget Guy

customer_reviews.title: meaning the photos were not really all that great. On top of this
customer_reviews.text: This was a very interesting concept, and my photographer wife thought it was quite novel. The problem is that this is what I would consider an "early concept", meaning the photos were not really all that great. On top of this, the app you need to download the images wouldn't run on her Mac, I think because the video card was too weak or something. Now it just sits there unused.

I have a good Nikon, a GoPro, cell phone, etc., and still play with the Lytro... so it is worth getting at the reduced price.

customer_reviews.title: Great if you can get it at a discount, don't pay full price.

The technology has a long ways to go before it justifies being in your camera case. But for those that want to live on the edge and hack and tweak things themselves this is an intriguing tool. Just don't pay full price.

customer_reviews.title: I was completely disappointed! The software doesn't work on my mac so ...
customer_reviews.text: I had wanted a Lytro for a long time. I finally purchased one as a birthday present to myself and once I got it, I was completely disappointed! The software doesn't work on my mac so I cant transfer any photos and the app crashes everytime I try to connect to the camera and transfer images. All in all it amounts to a whole lot of nothing. Really sad. Ultimately I returned it because I couldn't do anything with it.
customer_reviews.author: Martin

customer_reviews.title: Bought as Gift & Was Returned
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this camera as a gift, on the request of the recipient. After having it for a week, the recipient asked that the item be returned. He liked the concept of the photo not having to be in focus, but overall, he didn't think the camera was worth the money being charged. He said the pictures are way too small and the camera doesn't work when taking photos of a moving subject. The recipient has other, better-quality (granted, it's bigger) camera equipment, and decided the Lytro wasn't something he wanted, after all.
customer_reviews.author: Dawn McCloskey

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the money (Yet)
customer_reviews.text: Neat item and I hope the company survives and improves the product but currently: (1) low light performance is poor (2) Photo size is very small (3) Photos slow to load (4) Concept is good but it is way too expensive for a camera that can not take the place of a regular camera...and who wants to carry this and a regular camera? (5) No video It did get some looks from people but thats the only positive thing.

product_meta.title: Lytro Light Field Camera, 16GB, Red Hot
product_meta.description:
Size:16 GB| Color:Red HotThe Lytro camera is the first consumer camera that records the entire light field-all the rays of light traveling in every direction through a scene-instead of a flat 2D image. Shoot first, focus later By capturing the light field, you can do incredible things. Like refocus pictures after you take them. This also means that the Lytro camera has no autofocus-and none of the shutter delay that comes with it. Do more than tell a story. Recreate it. Refocus to discover new elements within the scene and move the picture in any direction to change your point of view with Perspective Shift. Use Living Filters to create a unique look. Now every picture you take is a chance to tell a new kind of story. Grip Made from precision-tooled silicone, the grip is easy to hold. Shutter Button The Lytro camera has no auto-focus - and none of the shutter delay that comes with it. Lens An 8x optical zoom lens with a constant f/2 aperture offers a wide range of creative shots. Touchscreen You control most of the camera functions with a tap or a swipe. And the backlit display lets you compose, review, and refocus your pictures. Light field sensor We joined a micro-lens array to a digital image sensor to capture the color, intensity, and direction of light entering the camera - 11 million light rays to be precise. Light field engine The light field engine processes the light rays captured by the sensor, so you can view pictures on the screen and refocus them with a tap. Battery Long-life Li-Ion internal battery lets you continue shooting without having to stop for a charge.

FROM THE MANUFACTURER
 

FROM THE MANUFACTURER
A NEW WAY TO TAKE AND EXPERIENCE PICTURES HAS ARRIVED. THE LYTRO CAMERA IS THE WORLD'S FIRST LIGHT FIELD CAMERA THAT ALLOWS YOU TO INSTANTLY CAPTURE INTERACTIVE “LIVING PICTURES” TO SHARE WITH YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY ONLINE.




The Lytro camera is the first consumer camera that records the entire light field—all the rays of light traveling in every direction through a scene—instead 
of a flat 2D image.

Shoot first, focus later


By capturing the light field, you can do incredible things. Like refocus pictures after you take them. This also means that the Lytro camera has no autofocus—and none of the shutter delay that comes with it.

Do more than tell a story. Recreate it. Refocus to discover new elements within the scene and move the picture in any direction to change your point of view with Perspective Shift. Use Living Filters to create a unique look. Now every picture you take is a chance to tell a new kind of story.


Get ready to share.
Share your pictures on Twitter, Facebook, Google+ or your blog and your friends can instantly refocus them and play with perspective shift just like you do.





EXTERIOR
Grip
Made from precision-tooled silicone, the grip is easy to hold.

Shutter button
The Lytro camera has no auto-focus — and none of the shutter delay that comes with it.

Lens


An 8x optical zoom lens with a constant f/2 aperture offers a wide range of creative shots.

Touchscreen


You control most of the camera functions with a tap or a swipe. And the backlit display lets you compose, review, and refocus your pictures.




INTERIOR
Light field sensor


We joined a micro-lens array to a digital image sensor to capture the color, intensity, and direction of light entering the camera — 11 million light rays to be precise.

Light field engine
The light field engine processes the light rays captured by the sensor, so you can view pictures on the screen and refocus them with a tap.




Battery
Long-life Li-Ion internal battery lets you continue shooting without having to stop for a charge.


SPECS
Size
41mm x 41mm x 112mm
Weight 214g



SOFTWARE INCLUDED

Import your pictures to your computer with the free Lytro Desktop application. With a couple of clicks, you can post to your personal page on Lytro Web, where your pictures will be stored for free*.
